title: Research
text:
Who Becomes a Criminal? (Master’s Thesis)
April, 2024
We investigate selection into criminality. Specifically, we use a noveldataset on inmates across 24 of 26 Brazilian states and rich administrative data to draw the profiles of criminals born between 1996 and 2002. We compare them with non-criminal individuals from the same cohort using a linearprobability model with year of birth and place fixed effects. Our findings suggest that criminals come from more urban and vulnerable places, with a higher exposure to other criminals. In addition, our results indicate that family structure matters and that parents of criminals are more economically vulnerable than parents of non-criminals. Finally, criminals have worse educational performance, a history of juvenile detention, and worse labor market performance.

title: Bernardo Duque
text:
Experience
I have worked as an research assistant in several projects since 2020. Some of the topics of these projects are the effects of pretrial detention arrest on recidivism; the expasion of drug-trafficking organizations in Rio; testing predictions of the median voter theorem; and investigating whether politicians keep their campaign promises after being elected.
I have also worked in the public sector as data analyst for the Research Center at the Public’s Attorney’s Office of Rio de Janeiro. I assisted research on militias and drug-trafficking organizations in Rio.
Further, I have experience in the private sector for consulting firms in Brazil, where I worked on projects related to economic analysis and policy evaluation.
